ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I learned how to write a good philosophy non-research paper; I learned the basics of several philosophers' ideas; I gained a sense of what a good philosophical discussion looks like. 
Along the way, I also discovered a passion for thinking about philosophical matters and even for writing out my own ideas in short essays. I'm really glad I came across such a wonderful teacher and such an excellent course that opens the door to professional philosophy learning for me.

Philosophical thinking
Insight into Western philosophy from ancient time to nowadays.
Basic philosophical thinking methods.
By taking this course I developed my reading skills and increase my philosophy knowledge that I was never exposed to.

Basic theory of some important philosophers;
A elegant way to make arguments

During the course I had the opportunity to learn about important philosophers of the western tradition such as Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, and Nietzsche. The course's rigorous readings and weekly essays allowed me the opportunity to manage my time efficientlly while thinking critically of the philosophical ideas that were prevalent in the course. I also learned the process behind actually doing philosophy and how to think when approaching philosophical questions and arguments.
I learned how to approach a philosophers writings and try to formulate my own response. The course helped instruct me on the right way to write arguments for the point Im making.

Through taking this course, I developed a solid foundation in philosophy and gained a deep understanding of key philosophical concepts and ideas. I learned to critically engage with the writings of influential philosophers from various time periods, such as Plato, Aristotle, Descartes, Kant, Nietzsche, and Simone de Beauvoir. This exposure to diverse perspectives allowed me to explore different philosophical approaches and consider the timeless questions that have shaped human thought.
I learned about questioning life.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The teacher is exceptionally great at explaining concepts. She speaks really eloquently and clearly. I can tell she is a really brilliant and logical thinker.
I also like the group discussion session we get every class, as I found it helpful to talk through the problems I've encountered with other classmates.

It would be more helpful if the teacher could guide the class to do some close reading to unpack some difficult paragraphs of the assigned readings. I believe that my skill of reading those difficult philosophical passages could really use some improvement.

Strength: Writing essays
Weakness: Speaking
Communicate more with the instructor and group mates.
May be the ethic parts are so much, but I enjoy it.
Reduce the number of readings

Strength: let students to discuss in very different groups with different students;
very logical

The strength of the course is its rigorous nature. The teaching staff did a great job of explaning the philosophical contents of the course, including those found in the readings and other ideas that might be brought up during class discussion. However, the course is extremely short, being just 5 weeks. This circumstance forced the professor to go through the contents of the course rather quickly, no doubt missing interesting information, which they have no fault of. The course would be greatly improved if the session was elongated to six or possibly seven weeks.
It was a comprehensive introduction to well-known philosophers and gave us a lot of room to respond to it; it didnt feel restrictive and allowed me to explore the ideas Im particularly interested in.

In reflecting on this course, I found several strengths that greatly contributed to my learning experience. One of the most notable strengths was the well-structured curriculum that carefully selected key philosophical works across different time periods and thinkers. This allowed me to trace the evolution of philosophical ideas and gain a comprehensive understanding of the subject matter.
I could improve by doing more work outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
Yes, I definitely would! 

As an intro course, this course has really accomplished its goal as a guide to the professional field of philosophy.
And for those who simply want to learn a thing or two about philosophy and don't plan to stay in the field, they will most certainly gain a lot as well. I think knowing something about the greatest philosophers that have ever lived is an essential part of our education. Much of the knowledge I get from this course is also applicable to other disciplines, for example, the definition of knowledge, propositional logic, logic fallacies, etc.
Furthermore, at least for me, discussing (or even arguing about) philosophical ideas with classmates is such an intellectually pleasant and fulfilling activity. It is a kind of happiness that you don't get in any other activity.
Lastly, this course has definitely improved my capacity for thinking clearly and writing clearly. 

Overall, good vibes all around!
Yes. It's excellent.
Yes.
Yes, I will recommend it to increase the knowledge of philosophers across different times and because this will develop other insights.
Yes. It is a great class for philosophy starters. More importantly, the instructor taught us how to argue, not only on philosophical issues.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in philosophy and rhetoric in particular. This is because the course covers these to fields very thoroughly, whether through essays and readings or class discussion. The course does have a heavy workload however, specifically there is a lot of reading and as such the student looking to enroll on the course must not have a problem with that.

I definitely recommend this course to newcomers to philosophy. Its very beginner-friendly and I didnt feel overwhelmed by the material. At times the readings were a little heavier than Im used to, but the lecturer will fill those gaps in class.

Absolutely, I would highly recommend this course to another student. The course's approach of introducing philosophy through foundational texts from various time periods provides an excellent opportunity to gain a comprehensive understanding of the subject. The readings are thoughtfully selected and cover a wide range of philosophical concerns, allowing for a well-rounded exploration of different perspectives.
Yes because it was good.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments:
Knowing something about the greatest philosophers that have ever lived is an essential part of our education. It also contributes to my all-round development. Much of the knowledge I get from this course is applicable to other disciplines, such as the definition of knowledge as justified true belief, propositional logic, logic fallacies, etc. I know that I will always come back to these fundamental concepts whenever I think about things and argue with people in the future.

In terms of skills, I've improved a lot on my academic reading and writing skills. Reading philosophy passages is hard in its own way. Lots of thinking, note-taking, and re-reading are required. I think that during the course of these few weeks, I have gradually gotten the hang of reading such passages, although I still have a long way to go. 
Philosophy paper writing is also unique. I always believe that thinking and writing go hand in hand. As I was writing the three short papers, I really came to terms with the fact that clear writing gives poor thinking nowhere to hide. Also, I feel that this course has made me get more fond of writing.
All in all, I know I will use the knowledge and skills I gained in this course for many years to come.
As a student focus on moral psychology, the knowledge of ethics will be applied to my research directly.

It will be easier for me to read philosophy in the future and comprehend more about this fascinating topic. I can engage in different topic conversations in the future with valid arguments and also challenge others ideas.

I will make my following essays more logical. 
I developed my own philosophical ideas on the world.

The most immediate application I can see for the knowledge I learned can be found in my Christian Anthropology class. In the class, we will be dealing with, among other things, philosophical ideas and questions relating to God. The knowledge I acquired in the course will certaintly help me discuss those ideas better. In general, philosophy also helps in expanding our perception of life and I will definitely be pursuing the topic later on.

Ive developed a new perspective for me to see the objects around me and the critical thinking skill. It is suitable for me who study more STEM subjects to approach a new subject which is the base of every subjects and our life.
This course has largely honed my logical thinking and academic writing skills, while clearing up some of my blind spots about the field of philosophy.

I can now engage in philosophical thinking much more readilyI have a better picture of what engage in philosophy looks like, and Im more confident in forming my papers. I understand how to give valid and sound arguments, too.

The knowledge and skills I acquired in this course will undoubtedly shape my future endeavors in meaningful ways. The critical thinking skills I developed through analyzing complex philosophical texts and evaluating arguments will be invaluable across various academic disciplines and in real-world decision-making scenarios.
To question things
